inscription:
観樹知異心　聴鳥知殊音　日出見山高　月來見水深　風行花自動　天寒魚自沈　静者無雑念　忘跡理可尋 (Gaze at the tree and know a different heart; / listen to birds and know a different sound. / The sun comes up—you see the hills are high; / the moon arrives—you see the water's deep. / The wind blows—the flowers move themselves. / One serene allows no mingled thought; / forget traces, then principle can be sought.) [Jonathan Chaves]

Poem: Kodōjin shiga no. 38 / Seisho sanbō shū no. 94
markings: poem UR red seal: 无心 {mushin} [mushin #3]; poem LL red seals: 字曰子徳 {azana iwaku Shitoku}, 静處 {seisho} [seisho #3]; LRC: 古道人 {Kodōjin} [Kodōjin #3]
signed: 庚辰春日古道人 {kanoe-tatsu shunjitsu Kodōjin} (Spring day in 1940, Kodōjin)
text:
観樹知異心　
聴鳥知殊音　
日出見山高　
月來見水深　
風行花自動　
天寒魚自沈　
靜者無雑念　
忘跡理可尋
Contemplating, grasping the mind with thoughts of departure,
Alone I seek to know extraordinary music.
The sun emerges—one sees the height of the mountains;
The moon arrives—one sees the water’s depth.
The wind blows—all the birds in motion;
The sky turns cold—fish naturally submerge.
In serenity, with no wild thoughts,
The forgotten path now can be found again.
	
Very few paintings and calligraphies by Kodōjon can be firmly dated to the 1940s; it is clear that Kodōjin was no longer as prolific as he once was. Quiet Setting of a Mountain Creek from the spring of 1940 is the last detailed landscape by him.
title: Quiet Setting of a Mountain Creek
